questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. On examination, he has a large nasopharyngeal mass with invasion into the surrounding bony structures and involvement of the intracranial space. Imaging studies reveal multiple lymph nodes in the neck, some of which are greater than 6 cm in size. There is no evidence of distant metastasis . What is the TNM staging of this cancer?
questions.explanation:
Category

Stage

Description

Primary Tumour (T)

T1

Tumour confined to the nasopharynx

T2

Tumour extends to soft tissues of the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity

T3

Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses

T4

Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx, orbit, or masticator space

Regional Lymph Nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), ≤6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa

N2

Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, ≤6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa

N3a

Metastasis greater than 6 cm in lymph node(s)

N3b

Metastasis in lymph node(s) in the supraclavicular fossa

Distant Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: In juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), which combination of molecular and genetic factors is most likely responsible for promoting both the proliferation of stromal cells and the enhancement of tumor growth through interactions with other pathways

options.label: D
options.text: Beta-catenin, Androgen receptor, and C-MYC proto-oncogene

questions.correct_answer: D. Beta-catenin, Androgen receptor, and C-MYC proto-oncogene
questions.explanation:
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Site of Origin

Posterior nasal cavity, near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen, where the sphenoid and palatine bones meet.

Gross Appearance

Reddish-purple, lobulated, sessile mass covered by mucosa; lacks a capsule despite being benign.

Microscopic Appearance
  • Vascular Tissue: Endothelium-lined spaces with incomplete/absent muscle coats, leading to bleeding; peripheral vessels are thin-walled, central vessels hyperplastic.
  • Stromal Cells: Stellate or spindle-shaped cells that produce collagen, affecting tumor firmness.

Immunohistochemistry
  • Fibroblasts, collagen, myofibroblasts, mast cells, and occasionally giant cells are present.
  • Reactivity to smooth muscle actin and beta-catenin, suggesting beta-catenin’s role in growth.

Growth Factors
  • JNA development likely results from a combination of hormonal influence, growth factors, and genetic factors.
  • Androgen Receptors: Present in 75% of JNA tumors, indicating male hormone involvement.
  • VEGF: Promotes endothelial and stromal cell growth.
  • IGF-II: Role is less clear.
  • Genetics: C-MYC proto-oncogene found in larger tumors; may interact with androgen receptor and beta-catenin genes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the ER with rapidly progressing swelling under the jaw and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is bilateral submandibular swelling with elevation of the tongue, but no trismus or fluctuation. He reports recent dental pain in his lower molars. Which anatomical connection is primarily responsible for the rapid bilateral spread of this infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Between the submental and parapharyngeal spaces

options.label: B
options.text: Between the sublingual and retropharyngeal spaces

options.label: C
options.text: Between the submandibular and submental spaces

options.label: D
options.text: Between the submental and buccal spaces

questions.correct_answer: C. Between the submandibular and submental spaces
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’ angina - Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces. (Option C)
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with bilateral submandibular swelling and difficulty swallowing. On examination the swelling is "woody-hard," and the patient exhibits trismus. A CECT scan confirms the presence of diffuse cellulitis without a well-formed abscess. Which of the following is the most critical initial step in managing this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer intravenous corticosteroids to reduce inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an intraoral incision and drainage to relieve pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Conduct a repeat contrast-enhanced CT scan to monitor progression

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate systemic broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’ angina

Clinical Features
  • General Symptoms: Severe difficulty swallowing (odynophagia) and varying degrees of trismus (difficulty opening the mouth).
  • Symptoms depend on infection location and extent:
    • Sublingual Space: Swelling in the floor of the mouth, pushing the tongue upward and backwards.
    • Submandibular Region: Swelling and tenderness in the submandibular area, often described as "woody-hard."
    • Progression: The tongue can displace upward and backward, potentially obstructing the airway, with possible laryngeal edema.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Evaluation: Assess symptoms, including swelling, tenderness, trismus, and airway compromise.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Ultrasound: Identifies abscess presence and location.
    • Contrast-enhanced CT Scan: Differentiates between abscess and cellulitis (Phlegmon), revealing infection extent.

Treatment
  • Systemic Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics to target mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
  • Incision and Drainage: Necessary if an abscess is present. (Option B ruled out)
    • Intraoral Approach: For infections confined to the sublingual space.
    • External Approach: For infections in the submandibular and submental spaces, involving a transverse incision along the mandible.
  • Airway Management: Maintaining a patent airway is crucial; tracheostomy may be needed in severe cases.

Complications
  • Spread of Infection: May extend to the parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces and potentially to the mediastinum, causing mediastinitis.
  • Airway Obstruction
  • Septicaemia
  • Aspiration Pneumonia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, chronic bad breath, and a gurgling sound in his neck during swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and neck pain. On examination, there is a unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall and neck stiffness with limited movement. A lateral neck X-ray reveals a widened prevertebral shadow. What is the etiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: C
options.text: Spread of infection from retropharyngeal lymph node

questions.correct_answer: A. Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall
questions.explanation:
Retropharyngeal space
  • Location: Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia.
  • Extent: From the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • Divisions: Two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) divided by a fibrous raphe.
  • Communication: with parapharyngeal space

Aetiology
  • Children under 3 years (common): suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes from infections in adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.
  • Adults: penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia
  • Breathing difficulty
  • Stridor
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall

Diagnosis
  • X-ray neck lateral view shows widened prevertebral shadow, sometimes even the presence of gas

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals the extent of the abscess

Treatment
  • Incision and drainage
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Tracheostomy if needed

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with chronic nasal obstruction, snoring, and mouth breathing. Physical examination reveals characteristic facial appearance as shown in the image and hypertrophy of the nasal turbinates. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected condition?
questions.explanation:
Adenoid Hypertrophy

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
    • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
    • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
    • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
    • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
    • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
    • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.

  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy (Option C), which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph (Option B): This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child was scheduled for elective adenoidectomy but developed an acute upper respiratory infection the day before the surgery. The child has no cleft palate or bleeding disorders. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Delay the surgery until the infection resolves

options.label: C
options.text: Start antibiotics and proceed with surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Discharge the patient with medical management

questions.correct_answer: B. Delay the surgery until the infection resolves
questions.explanation:
Indications & Contraindications of Adenoidectomy

Indications
  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea, or speech abnormalities (rhinolalia clausa).
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis.
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion linked to adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis.
  • Preventing recurrence of dental malocclusion after orthodontic treatment.

Contraindications
  • Cleft palate or submucous palate (risk of velopharyngeal insufficiency).
  • Hemorrhagic diathesis.
  • Acute upper respiratory infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child undergoes an adenoidectomy. Following the surgery, the child is monitored for potential complications. Which of the following is not a recognised complication of adenoidectomy?
questions.explanation:
Adenoidectomy

Anesthesia

General with oral endotracheal intubation.

Position

Rose’s position.

Procedure
  • Preparation: Insert Boyle-Davis mouth gag. Examine the nasopharynx with a tongue depressor and digital palpation.
  • Adenoid Removal: Use a curette with a guard to engage and remove adenoids. Lateral masses are removed with smaller curettes, and any remaining tissue is extracted with punch forceps.
  • Hemostasis: Achieved by packing the area. Persistent bleeding may require electrocoagulation or a postnasal pack for 24 hours.

Endoscopic Techniques
  • Debrider: For precise removal under endoscopic control.
  • Coblation: Uses radiofrequency to create a plasma field for removal.

questions.text: During a tonsillectomy, injury to structures within the tonsillar bed may result in significant complications. Which of the following structures is not directly associated with the tonsillar bed but can be affected by deep dissection or improper technique?
questions.explanation:
Structures forming Tonsillar bed

Muscles forming the tonsillar bed
  • Superior Constrictor Muscle
  • Styloglossus Muscle

Structures close to the tonsillar bed (outside the superior constrictor muscle)
  • Facial Artery (Tonsillar Branch): Major blood supply to the tonsils, at risk for haemorrhage during surgery.
  • Paratonsillar Vein: Venous drainage of the tonsil, risk of bleeding during tonsillectomy.
  • Submandibular Salivary Gland
  • Posterior Belly of Digastric Muscle
  • Medial Pterygoid Muscle
  • Mandible
  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the tonsils.
